 Talk How to Set Up a Second Monitor with Windows 10   
 Dual monitors are commonly used in work environments, but can be useful just about anywhere. One of the most popular usages for a dual monitor setup is to extend your display to two desktops for a more broad space. With an extended desktop, you can have more windows open, thus giving you more ability to multitask. In the next few steps, you will learn how to set up a second monitor for your laptop/computer. 
 Steps Edit 
 Part One of Three: Preparing Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/86\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-1.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/86\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-1.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 1 
 Make sure your computer can support a second monitor.  Not all graphics cards can support multiple monitors. If your computer can not support more than one monitor, then this will not work. You could try right-clicking on the desktop and select "Graphics Properties..", or see here for 3 ways to  Find Out What Graphics Card You Have 
 Another easy way to find out is that if the graphics card has to places to connect your cable to. In the image above, the graphics card has two VGA ports. This graphics card should support two monitors. 
 Most laptops come with a little sticker that states all the computers specs (hardware). 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/27\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-2.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/27\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-2.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 2 
 Buy the cable.  You should be able to use a VGA, DVI, or HDMI cable to hook up the second monitor.
 VGA, DVI and HDMI cables can range in price from approximately $5 USD to $30 USD on Amazon.com depending on length. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cf\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-3.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cf\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-3.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 3 
 Buy the monitor.  Monitors can really range in price from about $25 USD to $400 USD depending on what you're looking for. When shopping for a monitor, make sure you do some research into what you're looking at.
 Advertisement 
 Part Two of Three: Setting Up the Second Monitor Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/45\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-4.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/45\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-4.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 1 
 Set up the environment.  You should have your two monitors sitting side-by-side or one above and one below. You could also place one in the basement and one in the attic, but side-by-side works the best.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/63\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-5.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/63\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-5.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 2 
 Turn on your computer and monitor.  You will need your computer to be running for this to work. You could follow these steps with your monitor and computer both turned off, but you will not see any results. Make sure they are both connected to a power source if needed.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/00\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-6.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/00\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-6.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 3 
 Plug in the cable.  You should be able to use a VGA, DVI, or HDMI cable to hook up the two monitors.
 Advertisement 
 Part Three of Three: Configuring the Monitor Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e2\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e2\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 1 
 Right click on your desktop.  This should open a list of options.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bc\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bc\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 2 
 Click "Display settings".  This will open up the display section in your computers settings. You can find the display settings option as the second last on the list.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6f\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6f\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 3 
 Click "Identify" to see which monitor is which.  This will help you when you're Configuring the monitors. A big box with an identifying number will show up on each screen.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 4 
 Drag the representation of your two monitors to the right position.  This will help your computer know how your two monitors are set up so it will work more fluently.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-11.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 5 
 Continue to make further configurations.  You can adjust the screen brightness, change the screen resolution (advanced settings) and more.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6e\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6e\/Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Second-Monitor-with-Windows-10-Step-12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334.25824175824,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.25274725275} 
 6 
 Apply your configurations.  Once you're done, hit the blue "Apply" button to apply your changes. After that, you can close down the settings window. That's it! You have set up your second monitor.

 My second monitor goes to power saving mode when I turn it on, and my desktop cannot detect another monitor. What happened? 
								Answered by  
								 77Ecrivan   
 It's possible that your monitor isn't properly connected to your computer. Ensure that it is fully plugged in and seated correctly. If this has no effect, then your cable or monitor might be defective. Test it with another cable. If it works with the second cable, then the first cable could be damaged. If it doesn't work with either, then there may be a problem with the monitor.
